item.title: Automating Android Unit Test Apps (Xamarin) Like A Pro
item.description:
First Off..

This article is for those of you out there who use Xamarin to write Android applications and want to automate the process of running your tests on an Android device. I’ll show you how you can set this up with relative ease.

Here is the process we want:

  1. CI Build Begins
  2. Produces the APK file containing my tests.
  3. Starts up an Emulator and boots an AVD
  4. Installs the tests APK onto the Android Device (Emulated)
  5. Kicks of the tests
  6. Reports back the test results.
  7. If using Team City the test all appear nicely in the UI - otherwise the results are in STDOUT.

Unit Test App (Android) - and it’s shortcomings.

It all begins with adding the unit tests project itself. Xamarin have provided a project type in Visual Studio called a “Unit Test App”. Add one of those projects to your Solution and define some tests.

Here are some tests:

  [TestFixture]
    public class TestsSample
    {

        [SetUp]
        public void Setup() { }


        [TearDown]
        public void Tear() { }

        [Test]
        public void Pass()
        {
            Console.WriteLine("test1");
            Assert.True(true);
        }

        [Test]
        public void Fail()
        {
            Assert.False(true);
        }

        [Test]
        [Ignore("another time")]
        public void Ignore()
        {
            Assert.True(false);
        }

        [Test]
        public void Inconclusive()
        {
            Assert.Inconclusive("Inconclusive");
        }
    }

```

### Shortcomings of Running these tests

Naturally, you may be thinking how do you now run these tests? Well by default you have to manually run them. This is an app. Starting the tests project in VSis like starting any other Android application - it should deploy the APK to your Android device, and launch the app, which then shows a UI, and you must click various buttons on said UI to run the various tests that you want to run MANUALLY.

### An enormous pain in the ass..

This ofcourse, is a rediculous way forward and we need to get these automated ASAP!

### The short answer

The short answer, is that we need to take a few steps to get these tests automated.. Read on..

### Step 1 - The NuGet Package

I created a NuGet package called [TestyDroid](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Xamarin.TestyDroid/). 

In order to write this tool, it's fair to say it has taken a fair bit of research and testing!

So - [Install the NuGet package to your tests project](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Xamarin.TestyDroid/)

It contains two things. Firstly, it contains a command line executable in it's tools folder, called TestyDroid.exe. This little command line will handle spinning up an emulator, installing your tests apk, and running all of your tests and reporting the results, and lastly terminating the emulator once done.

Secondly, it contains an Android library that is added to your Android tests project as a reference. This library includes an improved base class that you will derive form instead of the default Xamrin one. We will cover this in the next step.

### Step 2

After that is installed, we need to address how these tests get "launched" in the first place.

Android has the concept of "Instrumentation"

`Instrumentation` are basically special types, that can be launched via an intent, and can run tests.

So, in order to "start" the tests running on the Android device (after the APK) has been installed, we need to create this "Instrumentation" class in our tests project. 

Add the following class to your Tests project:

Imortant to <span style="color: #0000FF">note</span> (adjust the Namespace appropriately) - the Instrumentation Attribute above the <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">class</span> <span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">has</span> a <span style="color: #BA2121">"Name"</span> property. THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT. Make sure it matches yoru <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">namespace</span> <span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">+ </span><span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">class</span> name, but with the <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">namespace</span> <span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">in</span> lower <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">case</span>.

So <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">if</span> you changed the <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">namespace</span> <span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">of</span> <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span> <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">class</span> <span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">to</span> MyCoolApp.Tests
And you changed the Class Name of <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span> <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">class</span> <span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">to</span> MyCoolTestInstrumentation
Then the Attribute above the MyCoolTestInstrumentation <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">class</span> <span style="color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold">should</span> look like <span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span>:

<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">1.</span></span> The path to <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">`</span></span>Adb.exe<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">`</span></span> (<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span></span> <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> your android-sdk<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">\</span></span>platform-tools directory)
<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">2.</span></span> The path to <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">`</span></span>Emulator.exe<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">`</span></span> (<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span></span> <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> your android-sdk<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">\</span></span>tools directory)
<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">3.</span></span> The path to your Tests APK file (I will give you a clue - it will probably be <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> your bin/release/ folder of your tests project!)
<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">4.</span></span> The name of the AVD that you would like to be launched <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> the emulator and used to run the tests <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">on</span></span>.

<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">###</span></span> Step <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">5</span></span> - Running On Team City

Once you have verified you can automate the tests locally, the next step <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> to <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">set</span></span> up your build system to run them during your build!

TestyDroid additionally supports reporting Test results <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> a TeamCity format so that they show up <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">as</span></span> test results <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> the TeamCity ui - <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">if</span></span> that<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">'</span></span>s your build system.  

To configure TeamCity it<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">'</span></span>s a <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">case</span></span> of:

<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">1.</span></span> An MSBUILD step to build your Tests project (csproj file) such that it outputs the APK (remember to use the target <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">`</span></span>SignAndroidPackage<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">`</span></span> to have the APK produced)
<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">2.</span></span> A command line step that calls <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">out</span></span> to Xamarin.TestyDroid.exe with the necessary arguments. 

The first step <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> easy, but the important thing to remember <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> to <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">set</span></span> the target to SignAndroidPackage

![tc commandlineparams testydroid.PNG](/img/tc commandlineparams testydroid.PNG)

That will now take care of producing the APK <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> the output directory <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">for</span></span> your project during your team city build.

The second step to create <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> the one that actually runs the tests <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>>using</span> <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #0000FF; font-weight: bold"</span>>TestyDroid</span>!
The follwing screenshot shows setting up a Command line step to <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">do</span></span> <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span></span>:
![tc testydroid commandlinestep.PNG](/img/tc testydroid commandlinestep.PNG)

<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">###</span></span> Step <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #666666"</span>><span style="color: #666666">6</span></span> - Admire your tests <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> Team City.
Now you can run a build - and <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">if</span></span> all <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> well - you should see your tests results added to a tests tab <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">in</span></span> Team City.

![tc Tests Tab.PNG](/img/tc Tests Tab.PNG)

<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"border: 1px solid #FF0000"</span>><span style="border: 1px solid #FF0000">###</span></span> Any Questions?
I have been someone limited <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">by</span></span> time so <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">this</span></span> was fairly rushed together! If there <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">is</span></span> anything you would like me to elaborate <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">on</span></span>, please leave a comment below.

Also you can read more information about TestyDroid <span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #008000; font-weight: bold"</span>><span style="color: #008000; font-weight: bold">on</span></span> Github: https:<span style=<span style="color: #BA2121">"color: #408080; font-style: italic"</span>><span style="color: #408080; font-style: italic">//github.com/dazinator/Xamarin.TestyDroid/wiki/Getting-Started</span></span>
